clinical_study.brief_title: Clinical Effectiveness of Bonded Versus Vacuum-formed Retainers
clinical_study.official_title: Clinical Effectiveness of Bonded Versus Vacuum-formed Retainers After 12 Months: A Randomized Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of the study will be to compare the clinical effectiveness of bonded versus vacuum-formed retainers regarding their retention capacity; periodontal health; survival rates; and patients' perception after 12 months of removal of fixed appliances.
The null hypotheses are that there is no difference between the retainers in relation to the aspects evaluated.

detailed_description.textblock:
This single-center randomized controlled trial will be performed at the Department of Orthodontics, Bauru Dental School, University of SÃ£o Paulo, Brazil.
A total of 50 patients completing orthodontic treatment will be recruited. The patients will be prospectively and randomly allocated into two groups. The first group will consist of 25 patients with canine-to-canine V-bend bonded retainers; while the second group will be composed of 25 patients with vacuum-formed retainers. In both groups, the same retainers will be installed in the maxillary and mandibular arches.
Patients will be evaluated at deboning (T0), after 3 months (T1), 6 months (T2), and 12 months (T3). In each appointment, digital models will be obtained and the other clinical variables will be evaluated. The primary and secondary outcomes will be compared between retainers in the time-points evaluated.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: This will be a 2-arm parallel randomized controlled trial. Therefore, the selected patients will be randomly divided into two groups. Group 1: Bonded V-bend retainers. Group 2: Vacuum-formed retainers. Randomization will be performed through sequentially numbered, opaque envelopes prepared by a colleague independent of the study.
study_design_info.masking_description: Masking of the principal investigator and participants will not be possible due to the nature of the interventions. Nonetheless, the outcome assessor will be blinded for the periodontal and patient perception variables.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Changes will be compared at T0 (Debonding); T1 (3 Months Follow-up); T2 (6 Months Follow-up); and T3 (12 Months Follow-up).
primary_outcome.description: Stability will be evaluated comparing the changes in the Little Irregularity Index (LII) between time-points. The average of the linear distances between the anatomical contact points of the anterior teeth will be considered.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Evaluation will be performed at T0 (Debonding); T1 (3 Months Follow-up); T2 (6 Months Follow-up); and T3 (12 Months Follow-up).
secondary_outcome.description: Distance between the cusp tips of the right and left permanent canines. In the maxilla and mandible.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Evaluation will be performed at T0 (Debonding); T1 (3 Months Follow-up); T2 (6 Months Follow-up); and T3 (12 Months Follow-up).
secondary_outcome.description: Distance between the tips of the mesiobuccal cusps of the first right and left permanent molars. In the maxilla and mandible.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Evaluation will be performed at T0 (Debonding); T1 (3 Months Follow-up); T2 (6 Months Follow-up); and T3 (12 Months Follow-up).
secondary_outcome.description: Distance between the incisal edge of the maxillary central incisor and the incisal edge of the mandibular incisor, parallel to the occlusal plane.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Evaluation will be performed at T0 (Debonding); T1 (3 Months Follow-up); T2 (6 Months Follow-up); and T3 (12 Months Follow-up).
secondary_outcome.description: Distance between the incisal edge of the upper central incisor and the incisal edge of the lower incisor, perpendicular to the occlusal plane.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Evaluation will be performed at T0 (Debonding); T1 (3 Months Follow-up); T2 (6 Months Follow-up); and T3 (12 Months Follow-up).
secondary_outcome.description: Periodontal status will be evaluated regarding the amount of calculus accumulation using the Simplified Oral Hygiene Index from Greene and Vermillion, 1978. The extension of calculus will be estimated visually in all erupted teeth. Each teeth will receive a score ranging from 0 to 3. Minor scores will indicate absence of calculus while higher scores will indicate greater calculus accumulation on the tooth surfaces.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Evaluation will be performed at T0 (Debonding); T1 (3 Months Follow-up); T2 (6 Months Follow-up); and T3 (12 Months Follow-up).
secondary_outcome.description: Periodontal status will be evaluated regarding the patients' gingival health using the Gingival Index described by Loe, 1967. The gingival health will be estimated clinically with a periodontal probe in all erupted teeth. Each teeth will receive a score ranging from 0 to 3. Minor scores will indicate acceptable gingival health while higher scores will indicate greater inflammation and unacceptable gingival health.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Evaluation will be performed at T0 (Debonding); T1 (3 Months Follow-up); T2 (6 Months Follow-up); and T3 (12 Months Follow-up).
secondary_outcome.description: Periodontal status will be evaluated regarding the amount of plaque accumulation using the Plaque Index from Loe, 1967. The extension of plaque will be estimated clinically using a periodontal probe in all erupted teeth. Each teeth will receive a score ranging from 0 to 3. Minor scores will indicate absence of plaque while higher scores will indicate greater plaque accumulation on the tooth surfaces.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Evaluation will be performed during the 12 Months of follow-up.
secondary_outcome.description: The number and cause of failures for each patient will be recorded during the 12-month follow-up. From these data, the total survival rate of the retainers will be estimated as a percentage, as well as its major causes of failure.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Evaluation will be performed at T0 (Debonding); T1 (3 Months Follow-up); T2 (6 Months Follow-up); and T3 (12 Months Follow-up).
secondary_outcome.description: Patients' perception will be assessed using a Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) containing a questionnaire with 9 questions related to the use of the retainers. Each question will receive a score ranging from 0 to 10. Minor scores will indicate that the patient felt extremely uncomfortable during the retention period while higher scores will indicate that the patients felt highly comfortable.

arm_group.description: The V-bend retainer is bonded in the lingual surface of the anterior teeth. The retainer is constructed using 0.024" stainless steel wires. Differently from the conventional bonded retainers, this retainer presents V-bends in the sagittal direction, parallel to the occlusal plane in each interproximal contact point of the incisors and canines. The retainers will be bonded after adequate etching with phosphoric acid and application of adhesive with a low viscosity resin.

The removable Vacuum-formed retainers will be made of acetate 1mm thickness. They will be made at the same appointment of debonding using plaster models. The patients will be instructed to use the retainers only during nights.

intervention.description: Traditional stainless steel retainer commonly bonded in the anterior teeth of the mandibular arch to maintain their alignment after orthodontic treatment.

Removable retainers made of plastic and derivatives. Currently gaining popularity due to the increased use of esthetic aligners. These clear retainers have the objective to maintain stable the results obtained after orthodontic treatment. They cover all the surfaces of the teeth up to the first or second molars.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients with the proper completion of orthodontic treatment and correction of the initial malocclusion.
- Acceptable oral hygiene (assessed through clinical examination).
- Presence of all teeth up to the second molars.
- Clinically acceptable teeth alignment.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients with any systemic condition that may have an influence on periodontal health.
- Patients with facial deformities.
- Initial malocclusion that required extreme corrections, large transverse expansions or orthognathic surgery.
- History of periodontal diseases.
